params.desc: Specifies the number of tweets to try and retrieve, up to a maximum of 200. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of tweets to return because suspended or deleted content is removed after the count has been applied. We include retweets in the count, even if include_rts is not supplied. It is recommended you always send include_rts=1 when using this API method.
params.name: count

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.
params.name: since_id

params.desc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.
params.name: max_id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: This parameter enhances the contributors element of the status response to include the screen_name of the contributor. By default only the user_id of the contributor is included.
params.name: contributor_details

params.desc: The entities node will be disincluded when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: The ID of the user for whom to return results for.
params.name: user_id

params.desc: The screen name of the user for whom to return results for.
params.name: screen_name

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.
params.name: since_id

params.desc: Specifies the number of tweets to try and retrieve, up to a maximum of 200 per distinct request. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of tweets to return because suspended or deleted content is removed after the count has been applied. We include retweets in the count, even if include_rts is not supplied. It is recommended you always send include_rts=1 when using this API method.
params.name: count

params.desc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.
params.name: max_id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: This parameter will prevent replies from appearing in the returned timeline. Using exclude_replies with the count parameter will mean you will receive up-to count tweets — this is because the count parameter retrieves that many tweets before filtering out retweets and replies. This parameter is only supported for JSON and XML responses.
params.name: exclude_replies

params.desc: This parameter enhances the contributors element of the status response to include the screen_name of the contributor. By default only the user_id of the contributor is included.
params.name: contributor_details

params.desc: When set to false, the timeline will strip any native retweets (though they will still count toward both the maximal length of the timeline and the slice selected by the count parameter). Note: If you’re using the trim_user parameter in conjunction with include_rts, the retweets will still contain a full user object.
params.name: include_rts

params.desc: Specifies the number of records to retrieve. Must be less than or equal to 200. Defaults to 20. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of tweets to return because suspended or deleted content is removed after the count has been applied.
params.name: count

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.
params.name: since_id

params.desc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.
params.name: max_id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: This parameter will prevent replies from appearing in the returned timeline. Using exclude_replies with the count parameter will mean you will receive up-to count tweets — this is because the count parameter retrieves that many tweets before filtering out retweets and replies.
params.name: exclude_replies

params.desc: This parameter enhances the contributors element of the status response to include the screen_name of the contributor. By default only the user_id of the contributor is included.
params.name: contributor_details

params.desc: The entities node will be disincluded when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: Specifies the number of records to retrieve. Must be less than or equal to 100. If omitted, 20 will be assumed.
params.name: count

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.
params.name: since_id

params.desc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.
params.name: max_id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: The tweet entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: The user entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_user_entities

params.desc: The numerical ID of the desired status.
params.name: id

params.desc: Specifies the number of records to retrieve. Must be less than or equal to 100.
params.name: count

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: The numerical ID of the desired Tweet.
params.name: id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, any Tweets returned that have been retweeted by the authenticating user will include an additional current_user_retweet node, containing the ID of the source status for the retweet.
params.name: include_my_retweet

params.desc: The entities node will be disincluded when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: The numerical ID of the desired status.
params.name: id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: The text of your status update, typically up to 140 characters. URL encode as necessary. t.co link wrapping may affect character counts.
params.name: status

params.desc: The ID of an existing status that the update is in reply to.
params.name: in_reply_to_status_id

params.desc: If you upload Tweet media that might be considered sensitive content such as nudity, violence, or medical procedures, you should set this value to true. See Media setting and best practices for more context. Defaults to false.
params.name: possibly_sensitive

params.desc: The latitude of the location this tweet refers to. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn’t a corresponding long parameter.
params.name: lat

params.desc: The longitude of the location this tweet refers to. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.
params.name: long

params.desc: A place in the world.
params.name: place_id

params.desc: Whether or not to put a pin on the exact coordinates a tweet has been sent from.
params.name: display_coordinates

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each Tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: A list of media_ids to associate with the Tweet. You may include up to 4 photos or 1 animated GIF or 1 video in a Tweet. See Uploading Media for further details on uploading media.
params.name: media_ids

params.desc: The numerical ID of the desired status.
params.name: id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: The numerical ID of the desired retweet status.
params.name: id

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: The text of your status update. URL encode as necessary. t.co link wrapping may affect character counts if the post contains URLs. You must additionally account for the characters_reserved_per_media per uploaded media, additionally accounting for space characters in between finalized URLs.
params.name: status

params.desc: Up to max_media_per_upload files may be specified in the request, each named media[]. Supported image formats are PNG, JPG and GIF, including animated GIFs of up to 3MB . This data must be either the raw image bytes or encoded as base64.
params.name: media[]

params.desc: Set to true for content which may not be suitable for every audience.
params.name: possibly_sensitive

params.desc: The ID of an existing status that the update is in reply to.
params.name: in_reply_to_status_id

params.desc: The latitude of the location this tweet refers to. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn’t a corresponding long parameter.
params.name: lat

params.desc: The longitude of the location this tweet refers to. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, not a number, geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.
params.name: long

params.desc: A place in the world identified by a Twitter place ID. Place IDs can be retrieved from geo/reverse_geocode.
params.name: place_id

params.desc: Whether or not to put a pin on the exact coordinates a tweet has been sent from.
params.name: display_coordinates

params.desc: The URL of the Tweet to be embedded.
params.name: url

params.desc: The maximum width of a rendered Tweet in whole pixels. This value must be between 220 and 550 inclusive. A supplied value under or over the allowed range will be returned as the minimum or maximum supported width respectively; the reset width value will be reflected in the returned width property.
params.name: maxwidth

params.desc: When set to true, t or 1 links in a Tweet are not expanded to photo, video, or link previews.
params.name: hide_media

params.desc: When set to true, t or 1 a collapsed version of the previous Tweet in a conversation thread will not be displayed when the requested Tweet is in reply to another Tweet.
params.name: hide_thread

params.desc: When set to true, t or 1 the <script> responsible for loading widgets.js will not be returned. Your webpages should include their own reference to widgets.js for use across all Twitter widgets including Embedded Tweets.
params.name: omit_script

params.desc: Specifies whether the embedded Tweet should be floated left, right, or center in the page relative to the parent element. Valid values are left, right, center, and none. Defaults to none, meaning no alignment styles are specified for the Tweet.
params.name: align

params.desc: A comma-separated list of Twitter usernames related to your content. This value will be forwarded to Tweet action intents if a viewer chooses to reply, favorite, or retweet the embedded Tweet.
params.name: related

params.desc: Request returned HTML and a rendered Tweet in the specified Twitter language supported by embedded Tweets.
params.name: lang

params.desc: Set to video to return a Twitter Video embed for the given Tweet.
params.name: widget_type

params.desc: Applies to video type only. Set to 1 or true to link directly to the Tweet URL instead of displaying a Tweet overlay when a viewer clicks on the Twitter bird logo.
params.name: hide_tweet

params.desc: The numerical ID of the desired status.
params.name: id

params.desc: Causes the list of IDs to be broken into pages of no more than 100 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 100 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.” The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See our cursor docs for more information. While this method supports the cursor parameter, the entire result set can be returned in a single cursored collection. Using the count parameter with this method will not provide segmented cursors for use with this parameter.
params.name: cursor

params.desc: Many programming environments will not consume our ids due to their size. Provide this option to have ids returned as strings instead.
params.name: stringify_ids

params.desc: A comma separated list of tweet IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.
params.name: id

params.desc: The entities node that may appear within embedded statuses will be disincluded when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.
params.name: trim_user

params.desc: When using the map parameter, tweets that do not exist or cannot be viewed by the current user will still have their key represented but with an explicitly null value paired with it
params.name: map

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.
params.name: since_id

params.desc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.
params.name: max_id

params.desc: Specifies the number of records to retrieve. Must be less than or equal to 200.
params.name: count

params.desc: Specifies the page of results to retrieve.
params.name: page

params.desc: The entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: The ID of the direct message.
params.name: id

params.desc: A UTF-8, URL-encoded search query of 500 characters maximum, including operators.  Queries may additionally be limited by complexity.
params.name: q

params.desc: Returns tweets by users located within a given radius of the given latitude/longitude. The location is preferentially taking from the Geotagging API, but will fall back to their Twitter profile. The parameter value is specified by “latitude,longitude,radius”, where radius units must be specified as either “mi” (miles) or “km” (kilometers). Note that you cannot use the near operator via the API to geocode arbitrary locations; however you can use this geocode parameter to search near geocodes directly. A maximum of 1,000 distinct “sub-regions” will be considered when using the radius modifier.
params.name: geocode

params.desc: Restricts tweets to the given language, given by an ISO 639-1 code. Language detection is best-effort.
params.name: lang

params.desc: Specify the language of the query you are sending (only ja is currently effective). This is intended for language-specific consumers and the default should work in the majority of cases.
params.name: locale

params.desc:
Optional. Specifies what type of search results you would prefer to receive. The current default is “recent.” Valid values include:
  * mixed: Include both popular and real time results in the response.
  * recent: return only the most recent results in the response
  * popular: return only the most popular results in the response.
params.name: result_type

params.desc: The number of tweets to return per page, up to a maximum of 100. Defaults to 15. This was formerly the “rpp” parameter in the old Search API.
params.name: count

params.desc: Returns tweets created before the given date. Date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD. Keep in mind that the search index has a 7-day limit.  In other words, no tweets will be found for a date older than one week.
params.name: until

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.
params.name: since_id

params.desc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.
params.name: max_id

params.desc: The entities node will be disincluded when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: If supplied, the response will use the JSONP format with a callback of the given name. The usefulness of this parameter is somewhat diminished by the requirement of authentication for requests to this endpoint.
params.name: callback

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.
params.name: since_id

params.desc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.
params.name: max_id

params.desc: Specifies the number of direct messages to try and retrieve, up to a maximum of 200. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of Tweets to return because suspended or deleted content is removed after the count has been applied.
params.name: count

params.desc: The entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.
params.name: skip_status

params.desc: The ID of the direct message to delete.
params.name: id

params.desc: The entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: The ID of the user who should receive the direct message. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.
params.name: user_id

params.desc: The screen name of the user who should receive the direct message. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.
params.name: screen_name

params.example: Meet me behind the cafeteria after school
params.desc: The text of your direct message. Be sure to URL encode as necessary, and keep the message within the character count limit (available in the help/configuration endpoint)
params.name: text

params.desc: Many programming environments will not consume our ids due to their size. Provide this option to have ids returned as strings instead. Read more about [node:194]. This parameter is especially important to use in Javascript environments.
params.name: stringify_ids

params.desc: The ID of the user for whom to return results for.
params.name: user_id

params.desc: The screen name of the user for whom to return results for.
params.name: screen_name

params.desc: Causes the list of connections to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.” The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.
params.name: cursor

params.desc: Many programming environments will not consume our Tweet ids due to their size. Provide this option to have ids returned as strings instead. More about Twitter IDs.
params.name: stringify_ids

params.desc: Specifies the number of IDs attempt retrieval of, up to a maximum of 5,000 per distinct request. The value of count is best thought of as a limit to the number of results to return. When using the count parameter with this method, it is wise to use a consistent count value across all requests to the same user’s collection. Usage of this parameter is encouraged in environments where all 5,000 IDs constitutes too large of a response.
params.name: count

params.desc: The screen name of the user for whom to return results for.

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1, statuses will not be included in the returned user objects. If set to any other value, statuses will be included.
params.name: skip_status

params.desc: The user object entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_user_entities

params.desc: A comma separated list of screen names, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

params.desc: A comma separated list of user IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.
params.name: user_id

params.desc: The entities node will not be included when set to false.

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user object.
params.name: skip_status

params.desc: Use of this parameter requires whitelisting.
params.name: include_email

params.desc: When set to true, t or 1, will enable sleep time for the user. Sleep time is the time when push or SMS notifications should not be sent to the user.
params.name: sleep_time_enabled

params.desc: The hour that sleep time should begin if it is enabled. The value for this parameter should be provided in ISO8601 format (i.e. 00-23). The time is considered to be in the same timezone as the user’s time_zone setting.
params.name: start_sleep_time

params.desc: The hour that sleep time should end if it is enabled. The value for this parameter should be provided in ISO8601 format (i.e. 00-23). The time is considered to be in the same timezone as the user’s time_zone setting.
params.name: end_sleep_time

params.desc: The timezone dates and times should be displayed in for the user. The timezone must be one of the Rails TimeZone names.
params.name: time_zone

params.desc: The Yahoo! Where On Earth ID to use as the user’s default trend location. Global information is available by using 1 as the WOEID. The woeid must be one of the locations returned by [node:59].
params.name: trend_location_woeid

params.desc: Whether to allow others to include user as contributor. Possible values include “all” (anyone can include user), “following” (only followers can include user) or “none”.
params.name: allow_contributor_request

params.desc: The language which Twitter should render in for this user. The language must be specified by the appropriate two letter ISO 639-1 representation. Currently supported languages are provided by this endpoint.
params.name: lang

params.desc: Full name associated with the profile. Maximum of 20 characters.
params.name: name

params.desc: URL associated with the profile. Will be prepended with “http://” if not present. Maximum of 100 characters.
params.name: url

params.desc: The city or country describing where the user of the account is located. The contents are not normalized or geocoded in any way. Maximum of 30 characters.
params.name: location

params.example: Flipped my wig at age 22 and it never grew back. Also: I work at Twitter.
params.desc: A description of the user owning the account. Maximum of 160 characters.
params.name: description

params.desc: Sets a hex value that controls the color scheme of links used on the authenticating user’s profile page on twitter.com. This must be a valid hexadecimal value, and may be either three or six characters (ex: F00 or FF0000).
params.name: profile_link_color

params.desc: The entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.desc: When set to either true, t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.
params.name: skip_status

params.desc: The avatar image for the profile, base64-encoded. Must be a valid GIF, JPG, or PNG image of less than 700 kilobytes in size. Images with width larger than 400 pixels will be scaled down. Animated GIFs will be converted to a static GIF of the first frame, removing the animation.
params.name: image

params.desc: The entities node will not be included when set to false.
params.name: include_entities

params.name: skip_status

params.name: skip_status

params.desc:
Causes the list of blocked users to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.” 
The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.
params.name: cursor

params.desc: Many programming environments will not consume our ids due to their size. Provide this option to have ids returned as strings instead. Read more about Twitter IDs.
params.name: stringify_ids

params.desc:
Causes the list of IDs to be broken into pages of no more than 5000 IDs at a time. The number of IDs returned is not guaranteed to be 5000 as suspended users are filtered out after connections are queried. If no cursor is provided, a value of -1 will be assumed, which is the first “page.” 
The response from the API will include a previous_cursor and next_cursor to allow paging back and forth. See Using cursors to navigate collections for more information.
params.name: cursor

params.desc: The number of pixels by which to offset the uploaded image from the top. Use with height, width, and offset_left to select the desired region of the image to use.

params.desc: Restricts the suggested categories to the requested language. The language must be specified by the appropriate two letter ISO 639-1 representation. Currently supported languages are provided by the GET help / languages API request. Unsupported language codes will receive English (en) results. If you use lang in this request, ensure you also include it when requesting the GET users / suggestions / :slug list.

params.name: count

params.desc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

params.desc: Entities are ON by default in API 1.1, each tweet includes a node called “entities”. This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. You can omit entities from the result by using include_entities=false

Provide values as returned in the response body’s next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list. It is recommended to always use cursors when the method supports them.  See [node:10362] for more information.
params.name: cursor

params.desc: The ID of the saved search.
params.name: id

params.desc: The query of the search the user would like to save. The query must be 100 characters or less.
params.name: query

params.desc: The ID of the saved search.
params.name: id

params.desc: A place in the world. These IDs can be retrieved from geo/reverse_geocode.
params.name: place_id

params.desc: The latitude to search around. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn’t a corresponding long parameter.
params.name: lat

params.desc: The longitude to search around. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.
params.name: long

params.desc: A hint on the “region” in which to search. If a number, then this is a radius in meters, but it can also take a string that is suffixed with ft to specify feet. If this is not passed in, then it is assumed to be 0m. If coming from a device, in practice, this value is whatever accuracy the device has measuring its location (whether it be coming from a GPS, WiFi triangulation, etc.).
params.name: accuracy

params.desc: This is the minimal granularity of place types to return and must be one of: poi, neighborhood, city, admin or country. If no granularity is provided for the request neighborhood is assumed. Setting this to city, for example, will find places which have a type of city, admin or country.
params.name: granularity

params.desc: A hint as to the number of results to return. This does not guarantee that the number of results returned will equal max_results, but instead informs how many “nearby” results to return. Ideally, only pass in the number of places you intend to display to the user here.
params.name: max_results

params.desc: If supplied, the response will use the JSONP format with a callback of the given name.
params.name: callback

params.desc: The latitude to search around. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn’t a corresponding long parameter.
params.name: lat

params.desc: The longitude to search around. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.
params.name: long

params.desc: Free-form text to match against while executing a geo-based query, best suited for finding nearby locations by name. Remember to URL encode the query.
params.name: query

params.desc: An IP address. Used when attempting to fix geolocation based off of the user’s IP address.
params.name: ip

params.desc: This is the minimal granularity of place types to return and must be one of: poi, neighborhood, city, admin or country. If no granularity is provided for the request neighborhood is assumed. Setting this to city, for example, will find places which have a type of city, admin or country.
params.name: granularity

params.desc: A hint on the “region” in which to search. If a number, then this is a radius in meters, but it can also take a string that is suffixed with ft to specify feet. If this is not passed in, then it is assumed to be 0m. If coming from a device, in practice, this value is whatever accuracy the device has measuring its location (whether it be coming from a GPS, WiFi triangulation, etc.).
params.name: accuracy

params.desc: A hint as to the number of results to return. This does not guarantee that the number of results returned will equal max_results, but instead informs how many “nearby” results to return. Ideally, only pass in the number of places you intend to display to the user here.
params.name: max_results

params.desc: This is the place_id which you would like to restrict the search results to. Setting this value means only places within the given place_id will be found. Specify a place_id. For example, to scope all results to places within “San Francisco, CA USA”, you would specify a place_id of “5a110d312052166f”
params.name: contained_within

params.desc: This parameter searches for places which have this given street address. There are other well-known, and application specific attributes available. Custom attributes are also permitted. Learn more about [node:208, title=”Place Attributes”].
params.name: attribute:street_address

params.desc: If supplied, the response will use the JSONP format with a callback of the given name.
params.name: callback

params.desc: The name a place is known as.
params.name: name

params.desc: The place_id within which the new place can be found. Try and be as close as possible with the containing place. For example, for a room in a building, set the contained_within as the building place_id.
params.name: contained_within

params.desc: The token found in the response from geo/similar_places.
params.name: token

params.desc: The latitude the place is located at. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn’t a corresponding long parameter.
params.name: lat

params.desc: The longitude the place is located at. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.
params.name: long

params.desc: This parameter searches for places which have this given street address. There are other well-known, and application specific attributes available. Custom attributes are also permitted. Learn more here.
params.name: attribute:street_address

params.desc: If supplied, the response will use the JSONP format with a callback of the given name.
params.name: callback

params.desc: The Yahoo! Where On Earth ID of the location to return trending information for. Global information is available by using 1 as the WOEID.
params.name: id

params.desc: Setting this equal to hashtags will remove all hashtags from the trends list.
params.name: exclude

params.desc: A comma-separated list of resource families you want to know the current rate limit disposition for. For best performance, only specify the resource families pertinent to your application.
params.name: resources

params.desc: If provided with a long parameter the available trend locations will be sorted by distance, nearest to furthest, to the co-ordinate pair. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (West is negative, East is positive) inclusive.
params.name: lat

params.desc: If provided with a lat parameter the available trend locations will be sorted by distance, nearest to furthest, to the co-ordinate pair. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (West is negative, East is positive) inclusive.
params.name: long

params.desc: The ID or screen_name of the user you want to report as a spammer. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.
params.name: screen_name

params.desc: The ID of the user you want to report as a spammer. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.
params.name: user_id
